Award.AwardTitle: Investigating Targets of Natural Selection for Hypoxic Adaptation at High Altitudes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Around 11,000 years ago, modern humans adapted to high altitude locations where the oxygen concentration is only 65% of that at sea level. This project seeks to identify the specific genetic changes that have allowed populations to survive at high elevations on the Andean Plateau. Findings from this research will advance our understanding of the ways in which modern human populations have been able to adapt to extreme environments through evolution by natural selection, and will also help to distinguish between natural selection and individual-level developmental adaptability. Improving our understanding of how the human body responds to low oxygen could inform the development of treatments for widespread diseases characterized by low oxygen, such as cancer and heart disease. The project will support student training and mentoring, and results of this study will be shared with the larger research community and integrated into public outreach programs aimed to encourage and financially support participation by underserved public middle school students.

Andeans exhibit a unique suite of physiologic adaptations to high altitude including a blunted hypoxic ventilatory response, elevated arterial oxygen saturation, and elevated hemoglobin concentration. Their ability to live in chronic hypoxia provides an unprecedented opportunity to examine the underlying mechanisms of their adaptation. Recent genomic studies have identified the gene EGLN1 as a high priority candidate locus for natural selection among Andean highlanders. However, the functionally important SNP/mutation(s) has not been identified. To address this gap in our knowledge, the investigators will study how genetic changes mechanistically translate into the dramatic Andean phenotype. They will rigorously characterize the strength of natural selection for two candidate functional SNPs using next generation sequencing technologies; link genotype to phenotype through association testing and mRNA expression analysis; and characterize their functional importance using a combination of Crispr technology and chromatin immunoprecipitation assays. By integrating evolutionary and functional approaches to the study of human high altitude adaptation, this research will provide critical insight into the molecular mechanisms governing functional, adaptive change. Additionally, project results will reveal how genetic changes translate into adaptive, fitness-related phenotypes. In so doing, the outcomes of this research will lead to a major change in our understanding of Andean adaptation for which developmental adaptation, as opposed to genetic adaptation, is often considered to be the main adaptive strategy. Furthermore, by contrasting these results to emerging data on the functional consequence of Tibetan EGLN1 genetic changes, this research is uniquely poised to definitively establish convergent evolution between Andeans and Tibetans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Andeans have inhabited the Andean Altiplano (average altitude of 12,000 feet) for up to 11,000 years. At this altitude, the partial pressure of oxygen is only 65% of that at sea level, yet Andeans have flourished under these harsh environmental conditions for millennia. This research set out to ask how Andean adaptation to high altitude occurred at the genomic level. In particular, we focused our efforts on changes to a single gene, EGLN1. This gene exhibits preliminary evidence of natural selection to high-altitude hypoxia among Andeans and plays a central role in the body’s hypoxic response as a key bodily oxygen sensor. We explored genetic associations with altitude-adaptive phenotypes using a cohort of Andean Quechua with varying exposure to high altitude over their lifetimes. This cohort consisted of three groups: 1) high-altitude Quechua who were born, raised, and resided at high altitude, recruited in the city of Cerro de Pasco, Peru (4,300 m); 2) migrant Quechua who were born in highland Peru (> 3,000 m) and down-migrated to low-altitude Lima, Peru (150 m) during their lifetime; and 3) low-altitude Quechua who were born and raised in Lima, Peru, but their parents and both sets of grandparents were born and raised in highland Peru (> 3,000 m). We demonstrated that genetic variants termed single nucleotide variants (SNVs) in or near EGLN1 were associated with maximal oxygen consumption (VO2MAX) during exercise. Our focus on the VO2MAX phenotype was based on our hypothesis that natural selection has operated on favorable molecular and/or physiological phenotypes that have resulted in high-frequency Andean population alleles that enhance systemic O2 delivery and/or cellular O2 use during exercise. In this way, the Andean higher VO2max can be conceptualized as either the phenotypic target of natural selection, or as a detectable outcome of natural selection on a related and unidentified phenotype. For each of the SNVs for which we identified an association, Andean Quechua exhibited the highest frequency compared to global allele frequencies determined among the populations of the 1000 Genomes Project. These findings lend further support to previous discoveries demonstrating natural selection at the EGLN1 locus among high-altitude Andeans. Furthermore, they provide the first evidence that natural selection has acted on EGLN1 to enhance oxygen delivery. Next, we examined the functional importance of EGLN1 SNPs in a panel of cell lines using Crispr technology to assess the impact of these SNPs on protein function, thus revealing how genetic changes translate into altitude-adaptive phenotypes. We demonstrated that deletion of a segment of EGLN1 intron 1 containing rs479200, a SNP enriched in high altitude-adapted Andeans and associated with the high VO2Max phenotype, results in lowered EGLN1 mRNA levels in A549 cells. This raises the possibility that the rs479200 SNP in Andeans might be an allele that affects EGLN1 mRNA levels to facilitate high-altitude adaptation.
